elements.content: Six novel coordination polymers based on a multifunctional ligand, 5,5′-(1,2-ethynyl)bis-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic (H4EBDC), namely, |(C3H7NO)2(H2O)7­(C2H5OH)3|[Zn2(C18H6O8)­(C10H8N2)2] (1), |(C3H7NO)3(H2O)30­(CH3CN)2|[Zn6(C18H6O8)3­(C6H12N2O2)2] (2), |(C3H7NO)2­(H2O)2(H3O)2­|[Cd3(C18H6O8)2] (3), |(C3H7NO)|­[Mn(C18H8O8)­(C3H7NO)2] (4), |(C3H7NO)2­(H2O)(C2H7N)3­|[Mn6(C18H7O8)4­(H2O)8] (5), and [Mn2(C18H6O8)­(C3H7NO)2] (6), have been constructed under solvothermal conditions and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In these compounds, the ligand, H4EBDC, exhibits different coordination modes and conformations, constructing various architectures by bridging a variety of metal ions or polynuclear clusters. Compound 1 forms a three-dimensional (3D) FSC network constructed from two-dimensional (2D) layer motifs joined by EBDC4– and 4,4′-bipyridine bridges. Compound 2 possesses an NbO topology by linking Zn2(CO2)4 units with the ligand, coordinated amine molecules fill the pores, while compound 3 exhibits a 3D FLU network with Cd2+ as the cation and features an infinite framework built from tricadmium clusters. Compound 4 is based on PtS net, constructed of 4-connected rectangular H4EBDC units with tetrahedral monometallic Mn(CO2)4 nodes. Compound 5 is composed of 2D layers with (3,6)-connected KGD topology, and compound 6 consists of a 3D PtS-X network, built by bridging a metal chain with the ligand. The structures of these compounds have been discussed together with their corresponding properties, such as gas storage, separation, and magnetic properties.

Compound 4 is based on PtS net, constructed of 4-connected rectangular H4EBDC units with tetrahedral monometallic Mn(CO2)4 nodes. elements.content: In recent years, the design and construction of coordination polymers have attracted increasing attention, and numerous coordination polymers have been reported not only because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also for their properties of high porosity and enormous internal surface areas. These properties have potential applications in clean energy, such as storage media for methane, hydrogen, and acetylene, or as absorbents or membrane fillers in separation and purifications of various chemicals. Besides the above-mentioned items, coordination polymers can also be used in catalysis, magnetism, luminosity, and chemical sensors. To date, impressive progress has been made on the theoretical forecasts and practical approaches of controlled syntheses of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the design and construction of coordination polymers have attracted increasing attention, and numerous coordination polymers have been reported not only because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also for their properties of high porosity and enormous internal surface areas. These properties have potential applications in clean energy, such as storage media for methane, hydrogen, and acetylene, or as absorbents or membrane fillers in separation and purifications of various chemicals. Besides the above-mentioned items, coordination polymers can also be used in catalysis, magnetism, luminosity, and chemical sensors. To date, impressive progress has been made on the theoretical forecasts and practical approaches of controlled syntheses of coordination polymers.

elements.content: The secondary building unit (SBU) has served as a popular organizing concept for the classification of the structure of coordination polymers. Generally, a coordination polymer contains two different SBUs: inorganic SBUs and organic SBUs. Inorganic SBUs, such as dimeric, trimeric, or tetrameric clusters, can be obtained by the aggregation of metal ions to carboxylate under different synthesis conditions, while the organic SBUs, including ditopic, tritopic, and tetratopic carboxylate ligands, can be utilized as linear linkers, triangular linkers, and square-planar or tetrahedral linkers to bridge inorganic SBUs, and result in coordination polymers with new, interesting, and fascinating structures. However, the control of aggregation of metal to carboxylate in design and synthesis of coordination polymers is challenging, because the process of aggregation is frequently modulated by various factors such as metal source, ligands, solvents, templates, pH value, temperature, metal–ligand ratio, and so on. Some synthetic strategies of elongation or modification of ligands (while maintaining the same inorganic nodes) under similar synthesis conditions are common, while exploration of structures from the same ligand and different inorganic nodes is less reported, especially using a rigid tetracarboxylate as the ligand. Rigid, elongated tetracarboxylate acids have often been employed as bridging ligands to construct coordination polymers, because this kind of ligand could act as a rectangular-planar 4-connected node, and the synthesized compounds have considerable applications. However, the inorganic nodes, which connect with these kinds of ligands, are mostly based on Cu(CO2)4 paddlewheel units, and only a few are based on tetrahedral nodes; thus, the reported coordination polymers exhibit NbO or PtS topologies. There is only one report containing indium trimer building blocks, which can be simplified as 6-connected nodes. The trimer unit is linked by H4ABTC ligand and showing SOC topology (H4ABTC = 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid). The other kinds of inorganic building units, which connect with tetracarboxylate acids, are less explored. Thus, the construction of new network topologies based on different inorganic building units, and further exploring the factors that affect their aggregation, is of great interest.

elements.content: Our group has focused on exploring alkyne functionalized tetracarboxylic acid ligands and their use to build new coordination polymers. H4EBDC, a tetracarboxylate acid having alkyne functionality, has also been used by other groups to construct coordination polymers. Though there have been several 3D coordination polymers reported, most of them present NbO networks based on [Cu2(CO2)4] or [Zn2(CO2)4] paddle wheel units. To speed up the discovery of coordination polymers based on the tetracarboxylate ligand with other kinds of inorganic building units and enrich examples of the H4EBDC ligand for the design of novel networks, we report six new coordination compounds with intriguing structures. Single crystal analyses reveal that their structures are constructed by different inorganic nodes, containing single-metal ions, binuclear clusters, trinuclear clusters, and metal chains. Interestingly, the H4EBDC ligand in compounds 3 and 5 is distorted and forms tetrahedral 4- or 3-connected nodes; these are different from previously reported linkers, which served as square-planar 4-connected nodes. Network topologies of these coordination polymers are examined. In addition, the gas adsorption, separation, and magnetic properties of the coordination polymers in the solid state have also been investigated.

elements.content: The ligand was prepared according to the literature. All the other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 4000–400 cm–1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on TGA Q500 V20.10 Build 36 thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range 35–700 °C under air flow with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. N2 and CO2 sorption isotherm measurements of the compounds were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained with SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-5) in the temperature range 2–300 K by using an applied field of 1000 Oe.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The ligand was prepared according to the literature. All the other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded within the 4000-400 cm-1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on TGA Q500 V20.10 Build 36 thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range 35-700 °C under air flow with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. N2 and CO2 sorption isotherm measurements of the compounds were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained with SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-5) in the temperature range 2-300 K by using an applied field of 1000 Oe.

elements.content: Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (10 mg, 0.034 mmol), 5,5′-(1,2-ethynyl)bis-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic (H4EBDC) (4 mg, 0.011 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy) (5 mg, 0.032 mmol), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL), EtOH (0.5 mL), and HNO3 (0.2 mL, 2.7 M in DMF) were added to a 20 mL vial at room temperature, and then the solution was heated to 85 °C for 20 h to give colorless, block-shaped crystals (10.3 mg, 0.0085 mmol, 76% yield based on H4EBDC). elements.content: The as-synthesized compounds 1–6 were insoluble in water and common organic solvents. The phase purity of as-synthesized samples was confirmed by the evident similarities between the calculated and the experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns (see Figure S5). The IR spectra for compounds 1–6 are shown in Figure S8.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of the compounds were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The intensity data of compounds 2 and 4 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID IP diffractometer and a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer for compounds 1, 3, 5, and 6 using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXTL Version 5.1. All the metal atoms were located first, and then the oxygen and carbon atoms of the compounds were subsequently found in difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed geometrically, and the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules could not be located but were included in the formula. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The final formulas were derived from crystallographic data combined with elemental and thermogravimetric analysis data. Crystallographic data for 1–6 (741833, 888080–888084) have been deposited with Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Data can be obtained free of charge upon request at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds are summarized in Table . Topology information for the compounds were obtained using TOPOS 4.0.

X-ray Structure Determinations

Suitable single crystals of the compounds were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The intensity data of compounds 2 and 4 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID IP diffractometer and a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer for compounds 1, 3, 5, and 6 using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXTL Version 5.1. All the metal atoms were located first, and then the oxygen and carbon atoms of the compounds were subsequently found in difference Fourier maps. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed geometrically, and the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules could not be located but were included in the formula. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The final formulas were derived from crystallographic data combined with elemental and thermogravimetric analysis data. Crystallographic data for 1-6 (741833, 888080-888084) have been deposited with Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Data can be obtained free of charge upon request at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds are summarized in Table . Topology information for the compounds were obtained using TOPOS 4.0.

Compounds 1–6 based on the H4EBDC ligand were all synthesized under solvothermal conditions. In order to verify whether the organic coligands replace the water molecules of the reported compounds with NbO topology, and then further influence the structures or the properties of coordination polymers, we kept the same ratio of metal to ligand with most of the reported synthesis conditions by using different organic coligands. Meantime, the experimental synthesis parameters such as solvent, temperature, and pH were also explored. In the process, we found that the stoichiometry of metal to ligand in the initial reaction would affect the quality of the final crystallized product, while the other parameters (solvent, temperature) play very important roles in the formation of the resultant polymer structures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Compounds 1-6 based on the H4EBDC ligand were all synthesized under solvothermal conditions. In order to verify whether the organic coligands replace the water molecules of the reported compounds with NbO topology, and then further influence the structures or the properties of coordination polymers, we kept the same ratio of metal to ligand with most of the reported synthesis conditions by using different organic coligands. Meantime, the experimental synthesis parameters such as solvent, temperature, and pH were also explored. In the process, we found that the stoichiometry of metal to ligand in the initial reaction would affect the quality of the final crystallized product, while the other parameters (solvent, temperature) play very important roles in the formation of the resultant polymer structures.

elements.content: The coordination chemistry of H4EBDC is interesting, since its four carboxylate groups can be partially or fully deprotonated to generate H2EBDC2–, HEBDC3–, and EBDC4– anions under different synthesis conditions. Therefore, it can coordinate with metal ions in multiple ways to form a series of coordination polymers with interesting topologies and properties. Furthermore, the side phenyl rings bearing two carboxylate groups in H4EBDC can twist around the middle alkyne to meet different coordination modes. Thus, the ligand has two different coordination conformations, coplanar and tetrahedral. Scheme shows eight coordination modes of H4EBDC (a–h): four coordination modes have been reported, including four 3D frameworks in (a) and (b) coordination modes, and two 2D layers in (f) and (g) coordination modes; the other four coordination modes of H4EBDC are first exhibited in compounds 1, 3, 4, and 5, which adopted (d), (c), (h), and (e) modes, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
The Known Coordination Modes of H4EBDC

The coordination chemistry of H4EBDC is interesting, since its four carboxylate groups can be partially or fully deprotonated to generate H2EBDC2-, HEBDC3-, and EBDC4- anions under different synthesis conditions. Therefore, it can coordinate with metal ions in multiple ways to form a series of coordination polymers with interesting topologies and properties. Furthermore, the side phenyl rings bearing two carboxylate groups in H4EBDC can twist around the middle alkyne to meet different coordination modes. Thus, the ligand has two different coordination conformations, coplanar and tetrahedral. Scheme  shows eight coordination modes of H4EBDC (a-h): four coordination modes have been reported, including four 3D frameworks in (a) and (b) coordination modes, and two 2D layers in (f) and (g) coordination modes; the other four coordination modes of H4EBDC are first exhibited in compounds 1, 3, 4, and 5, which adopted (d), (c), (h), and (e) modes, respectively.

elements.content:
Color scheme: carbon, gray; oxygen, red; metal, green.

Crystal Structure of <bold>1</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 1 is a 3D neutral framework in the solid state. It crystallizes in the Pbam space group. There is only one crystallographically independent zinc atom, which is coordinated with a O3N2 donor set coming from three EBDC4– ligands in an equatorial plane and two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4′-bipy ligands occupying the axial positions. The average length of the Zn–O bond is 1.988 Å, slightly shorter than the Zn–N bond (avg. 2.193 Å). It is noted that the Zn1–O5 distance is 2.867 Å, suggesting a non-negligible interaction between the zinc atom and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom. Each EBDC4– ligand connects with six zinc ions, two carboxylate groups adopt monodentate coordination mode, and the other two are in bridging bis-bidentate coordination mode. The carboxylate groups adopt the bridging bis-bidentate fashion to connect the two Zn ions and form a dinuclear unit with the Zn···Zn distance about 3.893 Å. Each Zn dinuclear unit is coordinated by four bipy N atoms and four carboxylate group ends from four EBDC4– ligands, which can be simplified into a 6-connected inorganic building unit (Figure a), and each ligand is coordinated with four dinuclear units to form a 4-connected rectangular node (Figure b). The dinuclear units are linked by the EBDC4– to form a 1D chain along the a direction (Figure c). These 1D chains are linked by the connection of a Zn1–O1 bond to give a 2D framework with (4, 4) net (Figure d and ). The resulting 2D sheets are further pillared by 4,4′-bipy to afford a 3D open framework with a channel of 9.3 Å × 11.4 Å (Figure e). The layers are stacked in an AA manner along the c axis to produce a 3D channel (). The accessible volume within the crystal is calculated to be 58.5% by using the program PLATON when the extra framework species are not considered. To better understand the framework topology, the compound 1 can be simplified as 4-connected rectangular planar nodes (organic linker) and 6-connected nodes (dinuclear building units); the assembly of these two types of nodes results in the generation of a 3D network having the FSC topology (Figure f and ).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 2 also adopts the dinuclear zinc cluster as the inorganic building unit, and the structure is extremely similar to the reported Cu(Zn)-compounds with slight differences. In 2, there is only one crystallographically independent zinc atom, which is five-coordinated and linked by four O atoms from four organic ligands; it is very interesting that the fifth O atom is from the 1, 4-diaza-bicyclo [2.2.2] octane-N,N′-dioxide. This must come from an in situ oxidation reaction, as we added only Dabco in the original solution. The EBDC4– ligand coordinates with eight zinc ions and the carboxylate groups are in bridging bis-bidentate coordination mode to connect the two Zn ions and generate a Zn2(CO2)4 paddle-wheel configuration, which can define a square-planar 4-connected node (Figure a). The distance of Zn···Zn in the paddle-wheel is 3.049 Å, the bond of Zn–Oamine is 1.976 Å, and the Zn–OEBDC 4– bond distance averages 2.031 Å. The ligand connects with four dinuclear paddle-wheel units Zn2(CO2)4 and can be simplified into a rectangular 4-connected node (Figure b). These two types of planar 4-connected nodes alternately connected, as expected, result in an NbO-type network of 64·82 topology (). The network can also be viewed as the packing and combination of two types of metal–ligand cages. The small cage consists of six inorganic SBUs; it is spherical, and the diameter is about 12 Å (see Figure c), while the large irregular one is encapsulated by 12 inorganic SBUs. It is ellipsoidal, and the diameter along the c axis is about 21 Å (see Figure d). There are two types of channel at the interconnections of the cages: the first type of channel can be viewed along the a or b axes (), and the other type is a hexagonal channel with a pore diameter of approximately 8.5 Å viewed along the c axis (). However, the hexagonal channel is filled with coordinated terminal oxidized Dabco molecules; as a result, the solvent-accessible volume of compound 2 is only 57.3%, which is lower than the reported Cu-compounds.

elements.content: When cadmium nitrate was introduced in place of zinc nitrate, and the synthesis condition was changed into a mixed solution of DMF and H2O, compound 3 was obtained. Compound 3 crystallizes in a triclinic system with space group P1̅ and displays a (4,8)-connected 3D framework built from trinuclear cadmium clusters and EBDC4– ligand. The fundamental building unit of compound 3 consists of two independent cadmium atoms that adopt different coordination environments, as shown in Figure a. The Cd(1) is coordinated with five oxygen atoms of four carboxylate groups from four EBDC4– ligands (Cd1–O = 2.187–2.337 Å), and Cd(2) has a distorted octahedral geometry with six carboxyl oxygen atoms from six different EBDC4– ligands (Cd2–O = 2.268–2.310 Å). Cd1 and Cd2 are interconnected by carboxyl groups to form a Cd1.5 unit, which further links its symmetric part through the ligands to construct a Cd3(CO2)8 inorganic building unit that can be simplified into an 8-connected node. The EBDC4– ligand coordinates with seven cadmium ions and the carboxylate groups exhibit interesting coordination modes as shown in Scheme c; two carboxylate groups are in bridging bismonodentate, another one is chelating bidentate, and the last one is for carboxylate oxygen bridges. Interestingly, the ligand connects with four inorganic Cd3(CO2)8 building unit and exhibits a structural transformation: two benzene rings severely twist to be nearly vertical around the middle alkynyl group, forming a 4-connected tetrahedral geometry node (Figure b). The inorganic Cd3(CO2)8 building unit and the ligand alternately connect and form a 3D open framework having rectangular channels with dimensions of 8.6 × 7.5 Å along the c axis (Figure c,d); other channels can also be viewed along the a or b axes with dimensions of about 7.0 × 5.6 Å and 7.5 × 7.0 Å (). To better understand the framework topology, compound 3 can be simplified as a combination of 4-connected nodes (organic linker) and 8-connected nodes (trimetric cluster building units), as shown in Figure a,b; the assembly of these two types of nodes results in the generation of a 3D network having the FLU topology (Figure e).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group, C2/c. It is constructed from Mn(CO2)4(DMF)2 units and H2EBDC2– units. Each manganese center exhibits slightly distorted octahedral geometry, defined by four monodentate carboxylates of four separate ligands and two coordinated DMF molecules (Mn–OH2EBDC 2– = 2.169 −2.186 Å, Mn–ODMF = 2.177 Å), and each ligand H2EBDC2– links four manganese ions to form a 3D framework through coordination of carboxylate O atoms. When the point-of-extension is considered, the center of the manganese unit is approximately a 4-connected tetrahedral node (Figure a), and the H2EBDC2– unit can act as a 4-connected rectangular node (Figure b). The tetrahedral nodes and the rectangular nodes alternately connect to generate the porous framework with PtS topology (Figure e). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 7.9 × 10.9 Å along the c axis (Figure c,d), which are filled with DMF molecules.

Crystal Structure of 4 

 Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group, C2/c. It is constructed from Mn(CO2)4(DMF)2 units and H2EBDC2- units. Each manganese center exhibits slightly distorted octahedral geometry, defined by four monodentate carboxylates of four separate ligands and two coordinated DMF molecules (Mn-OH2EBDC 2- = 2.169 -2.186 Å, Mn-ODMF = 2.177 Å), and each ligand H2EBDC2- links four manganese ions to form a 3D framework through coordination of carboxylate O atoms. When the point-of-extension is considered, the center of the manganese unit is approximately a 4-connected tetrahedral node (Figure a), and the H2EBDC2- unit can act as a 4-connected rectangular node (Figure b). The tetrahedral nodes and the rectangular nodes alternately connect to generate the porous framework with PtS topology (Figure e). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 7.9 × 10.9 Å along the c axis (Figure c,d), which are filled with DMF molecules.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallized in the monoclinic space group, P21/c, and features a 3D supermolecular framework. There are two crystallographically independent manganese atoms as shown in Figure a. Mn(1) is coordinated with five oxygen atoms, being surrounded by three HEBDC3– ligands and two guest water molecules (Mn1–OHEBDC 3– = 2.052–2.256 Å, Mn1–Owater = 2.145, 2.185 Å), and Mn(2) has a distorted octahedral configuration, defined by six carboxylate O atoms from different HEBDC3– ligands (Mn2–OHEBDC 3– = 2.157–2.247 Å). Mn1 and Mn2 are interconnected by carboxyl groups to form a Mn1.5 unit, which further links its symmetric part through the ligands to construct a Mn3 inorganic building unit; the unit can be simplified as a 6-connected node. The HEBDC3– ligand coordinates with six manganese ions and the carboxylate groups also exhibit interesting coordination modes (Scheme e): two carboxylate groups are in bridging bismonodentate, another one is for carboxylate oxygen bridges, and the last one is no coordination. The ligand in compound 5 also exhibits a structural transformation: the two benzene rings of the ligand twist, forming a tetrahedral conformation. However, the ligand only coordinates with three different inorganic building units, and thus forms a 3-connected node (Figure b). The assembly of these two types of nodes results in compound 5, which consists of stacks of 2D layers of the KGD (3,6)-connected network (Figure c,d). Furthermore, the coordinated terminal water molecules interconnect with the uncoordinated carboxylate group of the ligand through hydrogen-bonds to form a 3D supermolecular framework (Figure e).

elements.content: Compound 6 also crystallized in the monoclinic space group, C2/c. Its fundamental building unit contains one manganese atom, one EBDC4– ligand, and one coordinated DMF molecule. Each manganese atom is surrounded by four EBDC4– ligands and one guest DMF molecule. The coordination geometry around manganese can be best described as a tetragonal pyramid defined by four carboxylate O atoms from the ligands and one from DMF (Mn–O = 2.054–2.194 Å). The EBDC4– ligand in compound 6 coordinates with eight manganese ions, and all the carboxylate groups exhibit syn-ant bridging bismonodentate coordination mode; that is different from those of compound 2, the carboxylate groups in compound 2 display syn-syn bridging mode.

Crystal Structure of 6 

Compound 6 also crystallized in the monoclinic space group, C2/c. Its fundamental building unit contains one manganese atom, one EBDC4- ligand, and one coordinated DMF molecule. Each manganese atom is surrounded by four EBDC4- ligands and one guest DMF molecule. The coordination geometry around manganese can be best described as a tetragonal pyramid defined by four carboxylate O atoms from the ligands and one from DMF (Mn-O = 2.054-2.194 Å). The EBDC4- ligand in compound 6 coordinates with eight manganese ions, and all the carboxylate groups exhibit syn-ant bridging bismonodentate coordination mode; that is different from those of compound 2, the carboxylate groups in compound 2 display syn-syn bridging mode.

elements.content: In compound 6, manganese atoms are bridged by carboxyl groups to form an infinite rod-shaped metal-carboxylate building unit; all the Mn–O–C rods are composed of tetrahedral manganese centers after removing the coordinated DMF molecules (Figure a). The rod connects with the others through EBDC4– ligands to form a 3D framework with rhombic channels measuring 10.4 × 10.4 Å (Figure b,c). The channels are filled with the coordinated DMF molecules. From a topological perspective, the Mn–O–C rods can be simplified as infinite distorted octahedra sharing corners; joining the rods through the 4-connected organic links results in a 3D net of the PtS-X topology (Figure d).

elements.content: By adjusting the synthesis conditions, diverse structures can be obtained during the aggregation of the H4EBDC with different metal sources, which should be attributed to the multiple coordination modes of the organic ligand. There exist five different coordination modes of the H4EBDC ligand in these complexes (Scheme ). The ligands in zinc coordination polymers adopt (d) and (a) mode, in which the carboxylate groups show monodentate and bridging bis-monodentate coordination. The organic amines, which most of time being the structure-directing agent or template or the agent to adjust pH value in the formation of coordination polymers, incorporate into zinc coordination frameworks on the configuration of ligands. In compound 1, 4,4′-bipy works as the pillars to afford 3D framework, while in compound 2, the oxidized Dabco molecules coordinate with the zinc center along the paddle-wheel axis. It is worth noting that the water molecule binds to the metal center along the paddle-wheel axis in the reported compounds based on the rigid tetracarboxylates, and the resulting compounds always exhibit NbO topology. The coordinated organic amines in compounds 1 and 2 not only satisfy the coordination requirement of the dinuclear metal centers but also influence the structures or the properties of final coordination polymers; at the same time, the coligand 4,4′-bipy also affects the coordination mode of the H4EBDC ligand, which should be responsible for compound 1 with lower thermal stability.

In compound 1, 4,4'-bipy works as the pillars to afford 3D framework, while in compound 2, the oxidized Dabco molecules coordinate with the zinc center along the paddle-wheel axis. It is worth noting that the water molecule binds to the metal center along the paddle-wheel axis in the reported compounds based on the rigid tetracarboxylates, and the resulting compounds always exhibit NbO topology. The coordinated organic amines in compounds 1 and 2 not only satisfy the coordination requirement of the dinuclear metal centers but also influence the structures or the properties of final coordination polymers; at the same time, the coligand 4,4'-bipy also affects the coordination mode of the H4EBDC ligand, which should be responsible for compound 1 with lower thermal stability.

elements.content: Besides Zn2+ and Cd2+ chosen as the metal source, Mn2+ was also used to construct coordination polymers. For Mn compounds (4–6), all of them were synthesized under the mixture solvent of DMF and water, and though we changed the stoichiometry of metal to ligand in the initial reaction, we found that it mainly influenced the quality and purity of the final crystallized product. For example, we use the ratio of metal to ligand around 2:3, 3:2, or 3:1 in the initial synthesized condition with 1 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of H2O at 85 °C for 20 h. We can easily get the pure PtS phase (compound 4) with or without extra acid. However, by extending the reaction time and with the extra acid, we would get KGD phase (compound 5) mixed with PtS phase. If we reduced the amount of water below 0.5 mL in the reaction, we would get mixed phases of PtS-X (compound 6) and PtS. The progress for getting pure phases of compounds 5 and 6 is interesting. We first analyze the differences among the structures of Mn compounds. For compounds 4–6, the ligands adopt (h), (e) and (a) coordination modes, the metal to ligand ratios are 1:1, 3:1 and 2:1 in 4, 5, and 6 respectively, and the metal ions aggregate carboxylate to form different inorganic building units: a monatomic Mn ion for 4, a trimeric Mn cluster for 5, and an infinite Mn chain for 6, these mean that an excess metal would be better in the reaction for getting multinuclear inorganic building units; besides, the ratio of the metal to ligand in compounds 5 and 6 also indicated that excess metal source would be better for synthesizing pure products. Considering a μ1,1,3-binding mode of the carboxylate group is found in compound 5, as far as we know, increasing the temperature would increase edge-sharing connectivity and higher coordination numbers for carboxylate groups. To confirm whether the temperature influences the structures of coordination polymers 4 and 5 or not, experiments of comparison were done. By keeping the same reaction conditions except for the temperature of the reaction, we got pure compounds 4 and 5 at 85 or 105 °C, respectively. It indicates that the aggregating process of 4 and 5 is temperature-dependent. The contrastive experiments were also done for compounds 4 and 6. Similarly, by keeping the same reaction conditions except for changing the amount of water from 1 to 0.20 mL, the phases changed from PtS to PtS-X; less water would lead to the formation of a new phase which is easily broken in the air and cannot be chosen for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. It indicates that the amount of solvent plays an important role in the formation of different coordination polymers. In summary, the changes of metallic ions, organic bases, temperature, and solvent would influence the structures of coordination polymers.

elements.content: The thermal stability of compounds 1–6 has been evaluated in the temperature range of 35–700 °C under an air atmosphere (, Figure S9). Compound 1 shows the first mass loss of 22.23% below 170 °C due to the release of three guest ethanol and seven water molecules (calcd 21.95%); the further weight loss of 12.26% between 180 and 330 °C could be associated with the release of two guest DMF molecules (calcd 12.15%); the weight loss occurring between 330 and 500 °C (51.90%) could be attributed to the decomposition of 4,4′-bipy and the organic ligand (calcd 52.38%); the postresidue of 13.61% is ZnO, which was tested by PXRD analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of compounds 1-6 has been evaluated in the temperature range of 35-700 °C under an air atmosphere (, Figure S9). Compound 1 shows the first mass loss of 22.23% below 170 °C due to the release of three guest ethanol and seven water molecules (calcd 21.95%); the further weight loss of 12.26% between 180 and 330 °C could be associated with the release of two guest DMF molecules (calcd 12.15%); the weight loss occurring between 330 and 500 °C (51.90%) could be attributed to the decomposition of 4,4'-bipy and the organic ligand (calcd 52.38%); the postresidue of 13.61% is ZnO, which was tested by PXRD analysis.

elements.content: The TG curve of 2 exhibits a major weight loss of 21.92% in the temperature range of 35–240 °C, corresponding to the loss of the CH3CN and H2O guest molecules (calcd 22.09%); the further weight decrease of 9.61% in the temperature of 240–320 °C corresponds to the release of the DMF molecules (calcd 9.32%). Upon further heating, the weight loss of 50.17% corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligand and the coordinated oxidized Dabco molecules (calcd 49.61%).

elements.content: For compound 3, the first mass loss of 5.67% below 140 °C is attributed to the removal of four water molecules (calcd 5.73%); the second weight loss of 10.74% from 140 to 340 °C corresponds to the release of DMF molecules (calcd 11.62%). Upon further heating, the weight loss of 52.35% occurring between 340 and 500 °C (52.03%) is attributed to organic ligands decomposition, and the final product is CdO.

The dimethylamine molecules are from the decomposition of the DMF molecules. Then, a sharp weight loss between 380 and 700 °C with a weight loss of 55.00% corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand. From powder X-ray diffraction, the final products are identified as a mixture of Mn2O3 and Mn3O4.

elements.content: The accessible volumes of the structures were estimated to be 58.5% for 1, 57.3% for 2, 41.5% for 3, 42.1% for 4 and 36.4% for 6 of the total volume without the guest molecules in the pores by calculating from the single-crystal structure with PLATON/SOLV. Before gas sorption experiments, the framework structural integrity of compounds 1–6 was evaluated using PXRD studies. Only compounds 1–3 maintained their crystallinity upon immersing the samples in common solvents such as dichloromethane, chloroform, acetone, acetonitrile, and ethanol for 24 h (see ), so we concentrated on the gas adsorption properties of these compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Properties

The accessible volumes of the structures were estimated to be 58.5% for 1, 57.3% for 2, 41.5% for 3, 42.1% for 4 and 36.4% for 6 of the total volume without the guest molecules in the pores by calculating from the single-crystal structure with PLATON/SOLV. Before gas sorption experiments, the framework structural integrity of compounds 1-6 was evaluated using PXRD studies. Only compounds 1-3 maintained their crystallinity upon immersing the samples in common solvents such as dichloromethane, chloroform, acetone, acetonitrile, and ethanol for 24 h (see ), so we concentrated on the gas adsorption properties of these compounds.

elements.content: The sorption measurements, using N2 and CO2 as the adsorptive gas, were carried out on the activated compounds. The activated compounds of 1–3 were obtained by drying the solvent-exchanged solid at 373 K for more than 12 h under a vacuum, respectively. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the evacuated compounds 1–3 are almost the same as that of the as-synthesized coordination polymers, indicating that the frameworks retains their structural integrity (). Activated frameworks 1 and 3 showed no adsorption of N2. While compound 2 revealed reversible typical type I N2 sorption isotherms (Figure ), the adsorption and desorption branches are closed without hysteresis. It takes up a significant amount of N2 at 77 K (414 cm3/g at 1 bar). The estimated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area was estimated to be 1363 m2/g, and the corresponding pore volume was 0.58 cm3/g, in good agreement with the theoretical value of 0.61 cm3/g. Though compound 2 has a structure similar to the Cu-compounds, the adsorption is much lower; this may be because the hexagonal channels were filled with coordinated terminal oxidized Dabco molecules, which could not be removed without loss of the porous framework structure.

The estimated Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was estimated to be 1363 m2/g, and the corresponding pore volume was 0.58 cm3/g, in good agreement with the theoretical value of 0.61 cm3/g. elements.content: N2 adsorption isotherms for 2 at 77 K. Filled and open circles represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 7  N2 adsorption isotherms for 2 at 77 K. Filled and open circles represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.

elements.content: The CO2 sorption isotherms of 1, 2 and 3 measured at 273 and 295 K are represented in Figure . The adsorption and desorption branches of the compounds show a slight hysteresis, which could be attributed to the presence of intercrystalline voids. There is no significant CO2 uptake for compound 1; the uptake is only about 17 cm3/g (0.76 mmol/g) at 273 K. Compound 2 exhibits a very high CO2 uptake capacity of 115 cm3/g (5.1 mmol/g) at 273 K; it has a CO2 uptake of 68 cm3/g (3.0 mmol/g) at 295 K. For 3, the uptake of CO2 increases quickly at low pressure and reaches 22 cm3/g and 15 cm3/g at 273 or 295 K at 200 Torr; with further increase in the pressure, the sorption amount achieves 33 cm3/g and 26 cm3/g at 760 Torr. Compound 2 exhibits the highest adsorption for CO2; it is due to its relative high internal surface areas, which could provide the opportunity for more CO2 efficient packing in the pores. Though compound 1 has the largest accessible volumes (58.5%), the channel size (∼9 Å) is also large enough to the kinetic diameter of N2 and CO2 (3.6 and 3.3 Å, respectively). It shows no N2 adsorption even at 77 K, and its CO2 adsorption is also the least. This may be attributed to the 1D channel systems not running along the crystallographic axis in the framework, while the channels along the c axis are not effective for the gas accessing.

elements.content: CO2 sorption isotherms for 1 (square), 2 (triangle), and 3 (circle) at temperature 273 K (black) and 295 K (red). Solid and open symbols represent adsorption and desorption, respectively.

elements.content: Considering compound 2 has rapid uptake of N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 273 K, the adsorption for CO2 and N2 at room temperature was explored. At 298 K, the maximum CO2 uptake is 2.5 mmol/g, compared with only 0.25 mmol/g for N2 (Figure ). The initial slopes of CO2 and N2 adsorption isotherms were calculated, and the ratio of the slopes was used to estimate the adsorption selectivity for CO2 and N2. The slope ratio (CO2/N2) of compound 2 is calculated to be about 15 (), indicating the framework has a preferential adsorption of CO2 over N2 at low pressure. This is probably because CO2 molecules have significant quadrupole moments, inducing a stronger interaction with the framework.

elements.content: Because of the significant selectivity of compound 3 for CO2 over N2, the breakthrough experiments were performed with compound 3. The result obtained from the separation of a N2/CO2 gas mixture (4:1 v/v) is shown in Figure . It showed that CO2 was retained in compound 3. The selective sorption of CO2 should be attributed to the small aperture of the channels, which may discriminate a gas with small kinetic diameter (CO2 3.3 Å) from a gas with a larger kinetic diameter (N2 3.6 Å). The result suggests that compound 3 may behave as a highly effective size-selective molecular sieve, which can discriminate CO2 and N2.

elements.content: Compounds 4–6 are all constructed by the manganese and the ligand H4EBDC; however, the inorganic SBUs are different. They are mononuclear for compound 4, trinuclear for compound 5 and metal chain for compound 6. The nearest Mn···Mn distances are 7.835 Å, 3.720 Å, and 3.672 Å, respectively, in these compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Compounds 4-6 are all constructed by the manganese and the ligand H4EBDC; however, the inorganic SBUs are different. They are mononuclear for compound 4, trinuclear for compound 5 and metal chain for compound 6. The nearest Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distances are 7.835 Å, 3.720 Å, and 3.672 Å, respectively, in these compounds.

elements.content: For compound 4, there is long bridging ligand between the Mn(II) ions due to this large separation, and thus it is inefficient in transmitting magnetic interactions, while the inorganic SBUs in compounds 5 and 6 have carboxylate bridging which can propagate magnetic properties. Thus, the magnetic properties of compounds 5 and 6 were investigated over the temperature range of 2–300 K at an applied field of 1000 Oe. Plots of χM T and χM –1 versus T for them are shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text: For compound 4, there is long bridging ligand between the Mn(II) ions due to this large separation, and thus it is inefficient in transmitting magnetic interactions, while the inorganic SBUs in compounds 5 and 6 have carboxylate bridging which can propagate magnetic properties. Thus, the magnetic properties of compounds 5 and 6 were investigated over the temperature range of 2-300 K at an applied field of 1000 Oe. Plots of χM T and χM -1 versus T for them are shown in Figure .

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χM T vs T and χM –1 vs T for 5 and 6 at 1000 Oe; the red line represents the best fit.
elements.clean_text: 11  Temperature dependence of χM T vs T and χM -1 vs T for 5 and 6 at 1000 Oe; the red line represents the best fit.

elements.content: Both of the compounds show a typical antiferromagnetic character. At room temperature, the experimental χM T value for compound 5 at room temperature is 4.36 cm3·K·mol–1, which is similar to the value expected for an isolated Mn(II) ion (4.37 cm3·K·mol–1), and decreases continuously to 1.30 cm3·K·mol–1at 2 K. The plot of χM –1 vs T above 100 K obeys the Curie–Weiss Law [χM = C/(T – θ)] with C = 4.51 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −6.67 K. Compound 6 has χM T vs T plots similar to that of 5, and negative values of θ, the experimental χM T value for 6 at room temperature equals 3.94 cm3·K·mol–1, lower than the value expected for an isolated Mn(II) ion. The χMT value decreases to 0.61 cm3·K·mol–1. Fitting of the χM –1 – T data above 100 K using the Curie–Weiss law gives the Curie constant of compound 6 of 4.36 cm3 K mol–1, and Weiss constant of −3.29 K. The decreasing χM T value and the negative value of θ for these two compounds indicate weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring Mn(II) ions, which is expected for Mn(II) ions bridged by carboxylate ligands.
elements.clean_text: Both of the compounds show a typical antiferromagnetic character. At room temperature, the experimental χM T value for compound 5 at room temperature is 4.36 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, which is similar to the value expected for an isolated Mn(II) ion (4.37 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1), and decreases continuously to 1.30 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1at 2 K. The plot of χM -1 vs T above 100 K obeys the Curie-Weiss Law [χM = C/(T - θ)] with C = 4.51 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -6.67 K. Compound 6 has χM T vs T plots similar to that of 5, and negative values of θ, the experimental χM T value for 6 at room temperature equals 3.94 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, lower than the value expected for an isolated Mn(II) ion. The χMT value decreases to 0.61 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. Fitting of the χM -1 - T data above 100 K using the Curie-Weiss law gives the Curie constant of compound 6 of 4.36 cm3 K mol-1, and Weiss constant of -3.29 K. The decreasing χM T value and the negative value of θ for these two compounds indicate weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring Mn(II) ions, which is expected for Mn(II) ions bridged by carboxylate ligands.

elements.content: It is interesting to point out some different structural features of compounds 5 and 6 for their different magnetic properties. Compound 5 is a 2D framework containing linear trinuclear Mn units (Mn1···Mn2···Mn1). Mn1 and Mn2 in each trinuclear unit are triply bridged by three carboxyl groups. O5 is connecting Mn1 and Mn2 and thus made a Mn1–O5–Mn2 angle of 111.404°. The Mn1···Mn2 separation is 3.720 Å in trinuclear unit, the shortest Mn···Mn distance between adjacent unit by H4EBDC is 9.317 Å, and the shortest Mn···Mn distance between two layer by hydrogen bond is 8.006 Å. The structural feature of compound 6 is the metal/COO chains composed of metal ions bridged by two different modes: syn-syn and anti-anti, the intranetwork Mn···Mn separations are 4.585 Å /3.672 Å via COO and 7.549 Å via H4EBDC. Taking these characteristics into consideration, we speculate that the efficient magnetic superexchange pathway mainly results from the trinuclear Mn unit or the Mn chains.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to point out some different structural features of compounds 5 and 6 for their different magnetic properties. Compound 5 is a 2D framework containing linear trinuclear Mn units (Mn1⋅⋅⋅Mn2⋅⋅⋅Mn1). Mn1 and Mn2 in each trinuclear unit are triply bridged by three carboxyl groups. O5 is connecting Mn1 and Mn2 and thus made a Mn1-O5-Mn2 angle of 111.404°. The Mn1⋅⋅⋅Mn2 separation is 3.720 Å in trinuclear unit, the shortest Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance between adjacent unit by H4EBDC is 9.317 Å, and the shortest Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance between two layer by hydrogen bond is 8.006 Å. The structural feature of compound 6 is the metal/COO chains composed of metal ions bridged by two different modes: syn-syn and anti-anti, the intranetwork Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separations are 4.585 Å /3.672 Å via COO and 7.549 Å via H4EBDC. Taking these characteristics into consideration, we speculate that the efficient magnetic superexchange pathway mainly results from the trinuclear Mn unit or the Mn chains.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully constructed six novel coordination polymers with different network topologies from the same ligand, H4EBDC, under varying solvothermal conditions. The investigation not only illustrates that structural diversities of coordination polymers can be achieved by changing the inorganic building unit but also provides new examples of the H4EBDC ligand for the design of novel frameworks. The compounds containing different transitional-metal clusters will enrich the field of coordination polymers based on multicarboxylate ligands. Gas adsorption properties indicate that compounds 2 and 3 are potential microporous materials for adsorptive separation of CO2 over N2. Further studies on constructing coordination frameworks based on such tetracarboxylate compounds are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully constructed six novel coordination polymers with different network topologies from the same ligand, H4EBDC, under varying solvothermal conditions. The investigation not only illustrates that structural diversities of coordination polymers can be achieved by changing the inorganic building unit but also provides new examples of the H4EBDC ligand for the design of novel frameworks. The compounds containing different transitional-metal clusters will enrich the field of coordination polymers based on multicarboxylate ligands. Gas adsorption properties indicate that compounds 2 and 3 are potential microporous materials for adsorptive separation of CO2 over N2. Further studies on constructing coordination frameworks based on such tetracarboxylate compounds are underway.

IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3424br, 2948m, 1657s, 1600s, 1429s, 1384s, 1298m, 1248m, 1180m, 1106s, 1007w, 779w, 673w, 544s, 512s, 438s.

Synthesis of Compound |(DMF)2(H2O)(Me2NH)3|[Mn6(HEBDC)4(H2O)8] (5)

MnCl2⋅4H2O (10 mg, 0.034 mmol), H4EBDC (10 mg, 0.026 mmol), DMF (1 mL), H2O(0.5 mL), and HNO3 (0.2 mL, 2.7 M in DMF) were added to a 20 mL vial at room temperature, the solution was heated to 105 °C for 20 h to give colorless, block-shaped crystals (6.8 mg, 0.0031 mmol, 47% yield based on H4EBDC). Elemental analysis for H81C84N5O43Mn6 (MW = 2178.20) (wt%): found C 46.89, H 3.51, N 3.66; calcd C 46.32, H 3.75, N 3.22. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3140br, 3066m, 2934w, 1674s, 1616s, 1577s, 1434s, 1370s, 1097s, 922m, 86s, 715s, 683m, 495m.

Synthesis of Compound [Mn2(EBDC)(DMF)2] (6)

MnCl2⋅4H2O (10 mg, 0.034 mmol), H4EBDC (5 mg, 0.013 mmol), DMF (1 mL), H2O (0.25 mL), and HNO3 (0.1 mL, 2.7 M in DMF) were added to a 20 mL vial at room temperature, the solution was heated to 85 °C for 20h to give colorless, block-shaped crystals (3.7 mg, 0.0061 mmol, 43% yield based on H4EBDC). Elemental analysis for H10C14NO5Mn (MW = 327.18) (wt%): found C 47.92, H 3.95, N 4.89; calcd C 47.54, H 3.32, N 4.62. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3416br, 3073m, 2924w, 1667s, 1609s, 1544s, 1434s, 1370s, 1104s, 935m, 780s, 709s, 670s, 514m, 476m.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of compounds 1–6 has been evaluated in the temperature range of 35–700 °C under an air atmosphere (, Figure S9). Compound 1 shows the first mass loss of 22.23% below 170 °C due to the release of three guest ethanol and seven water molecules (calcd 21.95%); the further weight loss of 12.26% between 180 and 330 °C could be associated with the release of two guest DMF molecules (calcd 12.15%); the weight loss occurring between 330 and 500 °C (51.90%) could be attributed to the decomposition of 4,4′-bipy and the organic ligand (calcd 52.38%); the postresidue of 13.61% is ZnO, which was tested by PXRD analysis.

The TG curve of 2 exhibits a major weight loss of 21.92% in the temperature range of 35–240 °C, corresponding to the loss of the CH3CN and H2O guest molecules (calcd 22.09%); the further weight decrease of 9.61% in the temperature of 240–320 °C corresponds to the release of the DMF molecules (calcd 9.32%). Upon further heating, the weight loss of 50.17% corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligand and the coordinated oxidized Dabco molecules (calcd 49.61%).

For compound 3, the first mass loss of 5.67% below 140 °C is attributed to the removal of four water molecules (calcd 5.73%); the second weight loss of 10.74% from 140 to 340 °C corresponds to the release of DMF molecules (calcd 11.62%). Upon further heating, the weight loss of 52.35% occurring between 340 and 500 °C (52.03%) is attributed to organic ligands decomposition, and the final product is CdO.

The TG curve of compound 4 shows the first mass loss of 10.68% below 230 °C due to the release of one guest DMF molecules (calcd 11.66%); the further weight loss 22.51% between 230 and 400 °C should be attributed to two coordinated DMF molecules (calcd 23.32%); the weight loss occurring between 400 and 700 °C (52.80%) could be attributed to the decomposition of the organic ligands (calcd 53.35%); the postresidue of 13.61% is Mn2O3, which has been tested by PXRD analysis.

Compound 5 shows the first weight loss (7.41%) below 170 °C due to the release of guest and coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.44%); the further weight loss of 13.24% between 170 and 370 °C should be attributed to the guest DMF and dimethylamine molecules (calcd 12.92%). The dimethylamine molecules are from the decomposition of the DMF molecules. Then, a sharp weight loss between 380 and 700 °C with a weight loss of 55.00% corresponds to the decomposition of the organic ligand. From powder X-ray diffraction, the final products are identified as a mixture of Mn2O3 and Mn3O4.

For compound 6, the first weight loss (23.82%) below 400 °C is attributed to the release of two coordinated DMF molecules (calcd 24.10%) and then a sharp weight loss (48.09%) from 400 to 700 °C corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands; the final products can also be identified as a mixture of Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 from the powder X-ray diffraction.

Gas Adsorption Properties

The accessible volumes of the structures were estimated to be 58.5% for 1, 57.3% for 2, 41.5% for 3, 42.1% for 4 and 36.4% for 6 of the total volume without the guest molecules in the pores by calculating from the single-crystal structure with PLATON/SOLV. Before gas sorption experiments, the framework structural integrity of compounds 1–6 was evaluated using PXRD studies. Only compounds 1–3 maintained their crystallinity upon immersing the samples in common solvents such as dichloromethane, chloroform, acetone, acetonitrile, and ethanol for 24 h (see ), so we concentrated on the gas adsorption properties of these compounds.

The sorption measurements, using N2 and CO2 as the adsorptive gas, were carried out on the activated compounds. The activated compounds of 1–3 were obtained by drying the solvent-exchanged solid at 373 K for more than 12 h under a vacuum, respectively. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the evacuated compounds 1–3 are almost the same as that of the as-synthesized coordination polymers, indicating that the frameworks retains their structural integrity (). Activated frameworks 1 and 3 showed no adsorption of N2. While compound 2 revealed reversible typical type I N2 sorption isotherms (Figure ), the adsorption and desorption branches are closed without hysteresis. It takes up a significant amount of N2 at 77 K (414 cm3/g at 1 bar). The estimated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area was estimated to be 1363 m2/g, and the corresponding pore volume was 0.58 cm3/g, in good agreement with the theoretical value of 0.61 cm3/g. Though compound 2 has a structure similar to the Cu-compounds, the adsorption is much lower; this may be because the hexagonal channels were filled with coordinated terminal oxidized Dabco molecules, which could not be removed without loss of the porous framework structure.

The CO2 sorption isotherms of 1, 2 and 3 measured at 273 and 295 K are represented in Figure . The adsorption and desorption branches of the compounds show a slight hysteresis, which could be attributed to the presence of intercrystalline voids. There is no significant CO2 uptake for compound 1; the uptake is only about 17 cm3/g (0.76 mmol/g) at 273 K. Compound 2 exhibits a very high CO2 uptake capacity of 115 cm3/g (5.1 mmol/g) at 273 K; it has a CO2 uptake of 68 cm3/g (3.0 mmol/g) at 295 K. For 3, the uptake of CO2 increases quickly at low pressure and reaches 22 cm3/g and 15 cm3/g at 273 or 295 K at 200 Torr; with further increase in the pressure, the sorption amount achieves 33 cm3/g and 26 cm3/g at 760 Torr. Compound 2 exhibits the highest adsorption for CO2; it is due to its relative high internal surface areas, which could provide the opportunity for more CO2 efficient packing in the pores. Though compound 1 has the largest accessible volumes (58.5%), the channel size (∼9 Å) is also large enough to the kinetic diameter of N2 and CO2 (3.6 and 3.3 Å, respectively). It shows no N2 adsorption even at 77 K, and its CO2 adsorption is also the least. This may be attributed to the 1D channel systems not running along the crystallographic axis in the framework, while the channels along the c axis are not effective for the gas accessing.

Considering compound 2 has rapid uptake of N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 273 K, the adsorption for CO2 and N2 at room temperature was explored. At 298 K, the maximum CO2 uptake is 2.5 mmol/g, compared with only 0.25 mmol/g for N2 (Figure ). The initial slopes of CO2 and N2 adsorption isotherms were calculated, and the ratio of the slopes was used to estimate the adsorption selectivity for CO2 and N2. The slope ratio (CO2/N2) of compound 2 is calculated to be about 15 (), indicating the framework has a preferential adsorption of CO2 over N2 at low pressure. This is probably because CO2 molecules have significant quadrupole moments, inducing a stronger interaction with the framework.

Both of the compounds show a typical antiferromagnetic character. At room temperature, the experimental χM T value for compound 5 at room temperature is 4.36 cm3·K·mol–1, which is similar to the value expected for an isolated Mn(II) ion (4.37 cm3·K·mol–1), and decreases continuously to 1.30 cm3·K·mol–1at 2 K. The plot of χM –1 vs T above 100 K obeys the Curie–Weiss Law [χM = C/(T – θ)] with C = 4.51 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −6.67 K. Compound 6 has χM T vs T plots similar to that of 5, and negative values of θ, the experimental χM T value for 6 at room temperature equals 3.94 cm3·K·mol–1, lower than the value expected for an isolated Mn(II) ion. The χMT value decreases to 0.61 cm3·K·mol–1. Fitting of the χM –1 – T data above 100 K using the Curie–Weiss law gives the Curie constant of compound 6 of 4.36 cm3 K mol–1, and Weiss constant of −3.29 K. The decreasing χM T value and the negative value of θ for these two compounds indicate weak antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring Mn(II) ions, which is expected for Mn(II) ions bridged by carboxylate ligands.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  The Known Coordination Modes for 5,5'-(1,2-Ethynyl)bis-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H4EBDC)      a Color scheme: carbon, gray; oxygen, red; metal, green.

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 1: (a) The coordination environment of each Zn atom can be simplified as a 6-connected node; (b) the organic ligand, EBDC4–, coordinates four Zn2 units and can be simplified into a 4-connected node; (c) Zn2 units coordinate the ligand to form a chain along the a direction; (d) the 1D chains are linked to form a 2D framework; (e) space-filling representation of the 3D framework; and (f) polyhedral view of the FSC net. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. (Hydrogen atoms and guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  A description of the structure of 1: (a) The coordination environment of each Zn atom can be simplified as a 6-connected node; (b) the organic ligand, EBDC4-, coordinates four Zn2 units and can be simplified into a 4-connected node; (c) Zn2 units coordinate the ligand to form a chain along the a direction; (d) the 1D chains are linked to form a 2D framework; (e) space-filling representation of the 3D framework; and (f) polyhedral view of the FSC net. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. (Hydrogen atoms and guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.)

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 2: (a) The Zn2(CO2)4 paddle-wheel unit, which can be viewed as a 4-connected node of square geometry (green); (b) the organic linker, EBDC4– unit, which coordinates to four Zn2(CO2)4 units that can be considered as 4-connected nodes (red, rectangular SBU); (c) the small cage constructed by six inorganic SBUs; (d) the large cage constructed by 12 inorganic SBUs. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, gray. (Hydrogen atoms, guest molecules, and terminal bases have been omitted for clarity.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  A description of the structure of 2: (a) The Zn2(CO2)4 paddle-wheel unit, which can be viewed as a 4-connected node of square geometry (green); (b) the organic linker, EBDC4- unit, which coordinates to four Zn2(CO2)4 units that can be considered as 4-connected nodes (red, rectangular SBU); (c) the small cage constructed by six inorganic SBUs; (d) the large cage constructed by 12 inorganic SBUs. Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, gray. (Hydrogen atoms, guest molecules, and terminal bases have been omitted for clarity.)

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 3: (a) The Cd3(CO2)8 unit, which can be viewed as an 8-connected node (green, inorganic SBU); (b) the organic ligand, EBDC4– unit, which coordinates to four Cd3(CO2)8 units and distorts so that it can be viewed as a tetrahedral 4-connected node (red); (c) infinite 3D framework with rectangular channels of about 8.6 Å × 7.5 Å along the c axis; (d) space-filling representation of the 3D framework, and (e) inorganic SBUs (green) and tetrahedral SBUs (red) form the FLU network. Color code: Cd, green; O, red; C, gray. (Hydrogen atoms, and guest molecules, have been omitted for clarity.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  A description of the structure of 3: (a) The Cd3(CO2)8 unit, which can be viewed as an 8-connected node (green, inorganic SBU); (b) the organic ligand, EBDC4- unit, which coordinates to four Cd3(CO2)8 units and distorts so that it can be viewed as a tetrahedral 4-connected node (red); (c) infinite 3D framework with rectangular channels of about 8.6 Å × 7.5 Å along the c axis; (d) space-filling representation of the 3D framework, and (e) inorganic SBUs (green) and tetrahedral SBUs (red) form the FLU network. Color code: Cd, green; O, red; C, gray. (Hydrogen atoms, and guest molecules, have been omitted for clarity.)

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 4: (a) The Mn(CO2)4 unit, which can be viewed as a 4-connected node with tetrahedral geometry (green); (b) the organic linker, H2EBDC2– unit, which coordinated to four Mn ions that can be viewed as a rectangular 4-connected node (red); (c) infinite 3D framework with rectangular channels of about 7.9 × 10.9 Å along the c axis; (d) space-filling representation of the 3D framework; (e) tetrahedral SBUs (green) and rectangular SBUs (red) form the PtS network. Color code: Mn, green; O, red; C, gray. (Hydrogen atoms, guest molecules, and terminal DMF molecules have been omitted for clarity.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  A description of the structure of 4: (a) The Mn(CO2)4 unit, which can be viewed as a 4-connected node with tetrahedral geometry (green); (b) the organic linker, H2EBDC2- unit, which coordinated to four Mn ions that can be viewed as a rectangular 4-connected node (red); (c) infinite 3D framework with rectangular channels of about 7.9 × 10.9 Å along the c axis; (d) space-filling representation of the 3D framework; (e) tetrahedral SBUs (green) and rectangular SBUs (red) form the PtS network. Color code: Mn, green; O, red; C, gray. (Hydrogen atoms, guest molecules, and terminal DMF molecules have been omitted for clarity.)

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 5: (a) Ball and stick representation of Mn3 coordinate six organic ligands, which can be viewed as a 6-connected node (green); (b) ball and stick representation of the organic ligand, which coordinates three inorganic Mn3 clusters and can be viewed as a 3-connected node (red); (c) Mn3 clusters connect the ligand to form a 2D layer; (d) 6-connected inorganic SBUs (green) and 3-connected organic SBUs connect to form a (3,6)-KGD network, and (e) a nonperspective view emphasizing the hydrogen bonding in the compound 5 structure. Only the hydrogen atoms on the water are shown. Color code: Mn, green; O, red; C, gray; H, white. (Guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  A description of the structure of 5: (a) Ball and stick representation of Mn3 coordinate six organic ligands, which can be viewed as a 6-connected node (green); (b) ball and stick representation of the organic ligand, which coordinates three inorganic Mn3 clusters and can be viewed as a 3-connected node (red); (c) Mn3 clusters connect the ligand to form a 2D layer; (d) 6-connected inorganic SBUs (green) and 3-connected organic SBUs connect to form a (3,6)-KGD network, and (e) a nonperspective view emphasizing the hydrogen bonding in the compound 5 structure. Only the hydrogen atoms on the water are shown. Color code: Mn, green; O, red; C, gray; H, white. (Guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.)

cln_elements.content: A description of the structure of 6: (a) Ball and stick representation of infinite rod-shaped building blocks and building blocks with Mn shown as polyhedron; the infinite metal chain can be simplified into distorted octahedral coordination sharing corners; (b) view of the crystalline framework with inorganic building blocks linked together via the ligand, H4EBDC; (c) space-filling representation of rhombic channels measuring 10.4 × 10.4 Å; (d) distorted octahedra (green) and rectangular SBUs (red) form the PtS-X network. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Mn, green. (Hydrogen atoms, guest molecules, and terminal DMF molecules have been omitted for clarity.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  A description of the structure of 6: (a) Ball and stick representation of infinite rod-shaped building blocks and building blocks with Mn shown as polyhedron; the infinite metal chain can be simplified into distorted octahedral coordination sharing corners; (b) view of the crystalline framework with inorganic building blocks linked together via the ligand, H4EBDC; (c) space-filling representation of rhombic channels measuring 10.4 × 10.4 Å; (d) distorted octahedra (green) and rectangular SBUs (red) form the PtS-X network. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Mn, green. (Hydrogen atoms, guest molecules, and terminal DMF molecules have been omitted for clarity.)
